channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Some Far-Right Accounts on Twitter Saw Surge in Followers, Researchers Say
item.description: It’s unclear if the activity was driven by Elon Musk’s takeover of the company.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel and Stuart A. Thompson
item.media:credit: William Woody for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Lauren Boebert, a Colorado Republican, during a debate last month.

item.title: Trump Says He’s ‘Very Happy’ About Musk’s Twitter Takeover
item.description: Former President Donald J. Trump said the social media platform was now in “sane hands” with Elon Musk at the helm.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy W. Peters
item.media:description: Elon Musk has said he believes the decision to ban former President Donald J. Trump was wrong.

item.title: The Rev. Calvin O. Butts III, Dynamic Harlem Pastor, Dies at 73
item.description: He led Abyssinian Baptist Church and helped revitalize his community by building housing, some of which he reserved for existing residents.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts
item.media:description: The Rev. Calvin O. Butts III, the longtime pastor of Abyssinian Baptist Church, at his office in Harlem in 1999.

item.title: Jerry Lee Lewis, a Rock ’n’ Roll Original, Dies at 87
item.description: With his pounding piano, his impassioned vocals and his incendiary performing style, Mr. Lewis lived up to his nickname, the Killer.
item.dc:creator: William Grimes
item.media:description: Jerry Lee Lewis in 1957. His incendiary performing style captured the essence of rock rebellion.

item.title: Scarred by War, Ukraine’s Children Face Years of Trauma
item.description: For countless Ukrainian children, the war has brought long-term physical and psychological injuries. Those who have suffered serious physical harm or the loss of a parent now face a challenging path forward.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Brendan Hoffman
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maryna Ponomariova, 6, whose left leg had to be amputated below the knee after a devastating attack on her home in Kherson, is now learning to walk again with the help of Nazar Borozniuk at Ohmadyt Children’s Hospital in Kviv, Ukraine, earlier this month.

item.title: The U.S. announces more military aid for Ukraine, including guided rockets and artillery ammunition.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.media:description: A U.S.-supplied M777 howitzer firing on Russian forces in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine in June.

item.title: Bad News for the Fed As Inflation and Wages Continue to Climb Rapidly
item.description: The Federal Reserve’s preferred inflation measure showed that price gains remained fast in September, and a gauge of wages it watches closely is climbing quickly.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman and Jeanna Smialek
item.media:credit: Amir Hamja for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shoppers in New York this week. Friday’s Personal Consumption Expenditures report underlined that for now, demand remains strong.

item.title: S&P 500 Rebounds After a Week of Mixed Messages From Big Tech
item.description: Investors, who have been closely watching company earnings reports for signs of economic headwinds, appeared to zero in on better-than-expected results from Apple.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Simonetti

item.title: Distressed Democrats Look to Obama to Boost Turnout
item.description: The former president is hitting the campaign trail, beginning in Georgia on Friday night, to try to help Democrats energize voters and regain momentum in key Senate races.
item.dc:creator: Maya King and Jonathan Weisman
item.media:description: Former President Barack Obama at the White House last month. He will be hitting the campaign trail in Georgia Friday night.

item.title: Oz Struggles to Woo Black Philadelphians in Senate Race
item.description: Dr. Mehmet Oz has been trying to reach Black voters in Pennsylvania’s most Democratic city as he runs for the Senate.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Mehmet Oz’s crime policy pitch in his race against John Fetterman includes supporting community policing, ending “sanctuary cities” and stopping fentanyl at the Southwest border.

item.title: The Shelf Life of a 12-Foot Home Depot Skeleton
item.description: Devotees have spent years hunting for a 12-foot skeleton introduced by the Home Depot in 2020. Can the hype survive?
item.dc:creator: Callie Holtermann
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nicknamed Skelly, the product has roughly 164 plastic bones, or about 80 percent of the 206 in an adult human body.

item.title: World Series Preview: Philadelphia Has an Edge on Houston
item.description: For a city that rarely reaches the top, Philadelphia has a strange pattern of success against Houston. The Astros will try to overcome that in the World Series against the Phillies.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Kepner
item.media:credit: Brett Coomer/Houston Chronicle, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Philadelphia’s strange run of sports success against Houston includes the Phillies clinching a playoff berth with a win over the Astros on Oct. 3.

item.title: Dark Tourism: Destinations of Death, Tragedy and the Macabre
item.description: Travelers who use their off time to visit places like the Chernobyl nuclear plant or current conflict zones say they no longer want a sanitized version of a troubled world.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Aokigahara forest in Japan, known as the suicide forest, is a dark tourism destination.

item.title: Congress Should Back This Promising Bill on Immigration
item.description: Congress needs to provide sufficient funding for an asylum system that admits those who qualify for refuge and keeps out those who don’t.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board
item.media:credit: Illustration by Rebecca Chew/The New York Times; photograph by MasterLu, via Getty Images

item.title: Elon Musk Is Buying Twitter. Shudder.
item.description: Rogue billionaires have appeared before, and they will appear again. But this one will control our “digital town square.”
item.dc:creator: David Nasaw

item.title: On Affirmative Action, What Once Seemed Unthinkable Might Become Real
item.description: Should diversity still be considered the compelling interest in college admissions that the court said it was in 1978?
item.dc:creator: Linda Greenhouse
item.category: Brown v Board of Education (Supreme Court Decision)

item.title: Xi Jinping vs. the People
item.description: How Chinese citizens are responding to Xi’s lengthened rule.
item.dc:creator: Li Yuan

item.title: Two Futures Face Off in Brazil
item.description: The fate of democracy is at stake in the nation’s most important election in decades.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise, Rachelle Bonja, Eric Krupke, Liz O. Baylen, Lisa Chow, Chelsea Daniel, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Voters in Brazil on Sunday will choose between two candidates who have very different visions for the country.

item.title: A Zuni Café Classic Without the Chicken? It’s Possible.
item.description: Try a warm bread salad with crisp mushrooms, inspired by the restaurant dish.
item.dc:creator: Tejal Rao

item.title: Italy’s Hard Right Feels Vindicated by Giorgia Meloni’s Ascent
item.description: Long marginalized politically and ostracized socially, the new prime minister’s supporters sense a chance to give a final blow to the stigma and shame of their association with Fascism.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo and Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of Giorgia Meloni at her final campaign rally in Rome before the election in September.

item.title: Kanye West Faces Costly Fallout
item.description: The entertainer has been widely condemned for a series of antisemitic comments. The fallout across industries has been swift.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin
item.media:credit: Nina Westervelt for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kanye West at a fashion show held by Vogue in September in New York.

item.title: In Retrial, Man Who Helped Run Border Wall Charity Is Convicted
item.description: Timothy Shea was the only one of four defendants in the federal case to face a jury. The former Trump adviser Stephen K. Bannon faces similar charges in state court.
item.dc:creator: Colin Moynihan
item.media:description: Timothy Shea was a central figure in raising $25 million for a barrier separating the United States from Mexico.

item.title: Menendez Inquiry Said to Involve Company That Certifies Halal Meat
item.description: Federal agents have been asking about IS EG Halal, a New Jersey firm that Egypt made its sole certifier for meat exports from America, an inquiry that appears to include Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey.
item.dc:creator: Tracey Tully, Benjamin Weiser and William K. Rashbaum
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Robert Menendez said on Friday he stands ready to help prosecutors “when and if they ask.”

item.title: How to Help Someone With Depression
item.description: Whether they are coping with seasonal symptoms or chronic depression, here’s how to offer love and understanding while still caring for yourself.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson

item.title: How Love Languages Became a Cultural Phenomenon
item.description: The author of the seminal book on love languages is surprised that the concept has become a cultural phenomenon. But he still wants couples to heed his advice.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta and Luis Mazón

item.title: Terrence Real’s Latest Book Explores Fixing What Ails Us
item.description: In his new book, ‘Us’, Terrence Real explores how ‘enlightened self interest’ could save your relationship.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Jones

item.title: How Online Dating Apps Can Lead to Burnout
item.description: Ten years after the launch of Tinder, some long-term online daters say endless swiping has been bad for their mental health.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson

item.title: Book Review: ‘The Seven Moons of Maali Almeida,’ by Shehan Karunatilaka
item.description: “The Seven Moons of Maali Almeida,” which won the 2022 Booker Prize, is an account of wartime Sri Lanka by the ghost of a photojournalist.
item.dc:creator: Randy Boyagoda
item.media:description: Colombo, Sri Lanka, in the 1990s. “The Seven Moons of Maali Almeida” examines life in Sri Lanka during its civil war.

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
